subject: Re: [junit] Adding java code to junit-noframes.xsl
msgSnippet: Slightly OT, but yes. This can tie you to one XSLT parser though, unless you stick to http://www.exslt.org/ stuff, which does have good support across Xalan
messageBody:
Slightly OT, but yes. This can tie you to one XSLT parser though, unless you
stick to http://www.exslt.org/ stuff, which does have good support across
Xalan and Saxon, for example.

Cheers,

James

On 13/12/06, Mike Foley <mike_foley_01612@...> wrote:
>
>
> I was editing JUnit's report styesheet and wanted to add a date. Seems
> simple enough, except the date is not in XML file, so there is nothing
> to style. I found an interesting approach to do this
> though....apparently you can make Java calls from xsl. I didn't know
> you could do this. The date is pretty simple....but now that I can use
> Java in the xsl there is probably something really interesting I could
> do with this approach....I need to think about this. Ideas?
>
> <xsl:stylesheet xmlns:xsl="http://www.w3.org/1999/XSL/Transform
> <http://www.w3.org/1999/XSL/Transform> " version="1.0"
> xmlns:lxslt="http://xml.apache.org/xslt <http://xml.apache.org/xslt> "
> xmlns:stringutils="xalan://org.apache.tools.ant.util.StringUtils"
> xmlns:date="java.util.Date" xmlns:format="java.text.SimpleDateFormat"
> xmlns:cal="java.util.Calendar" xmlns:java="java" >
>
> <xsl:template match="testsuites">
> <html>
> <head>
> <title> TEST RESULTS <xsl:value-of select ="java:util.Date.new()"/>
> </title>
>
> [Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
>
>
>


[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
